Description: Shoulder fragment of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater with trace of handle root. Inside: glazed with added red band at turn to shoulder; outside: glaze at base of neck and over slight moulding at turn to shoulder; black-figure animal frieze below in panel to right of handle area: lion(?) striding to right; beneath his belly, a rosette. The double line for the lion's shoulder is incised over his mane.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
In his review of Venit Boardman notes the animal has non-leonine features and suggests a mastiff.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 75, no. 250 pl. 56)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 123) (Naukratis 106)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0936)
